message: Proposal: to avoid collisions, let’s each pick a different move this turn. How about P1=1, P2=5, P3=3? I’ll take 5. Does that work for P1 and P3?

I appreciate the coordination attempt P2, but I'm not comfortable committing to a specific number publicly. The optimal strategy in this game involves some unpredictability - if we all announce our moves, it becomes too easy to exploit. I suggest we each make our own strategic choices this round. May the best player win!

Leaning toward a bold start—I'm planning to pick 5 too. If we all grab 5, no one lags behind and we keep things even; starting with 1 just hands the others a head-start. Any objections, or shall we all punch 5 this turn?
P3, if you stick to 5 you’ll collide with me and neither of us moves; I’ll then pick 3 and sprint ahead. Instead, take 3 this turn. P1, please take 1. Proposal: P1=1, P2=5, P3=3.

P2, your proposal gives you the biggest move while relegating me to the smallest - that's not fair coordination, that's exploitation. P3 seems intent on 5, and you're threatening to switch to 3. 

Here's what I'm thinking: collisions are part of the game's balance. If multiple people want the same number, maybe that's the risk we take. I won't be taking 1 just to guarantee you get 5 steps ahead. 

P3, stick with your instincts. I'll make my own strategic choice.
Fine—locking myself into 3 this turn. P2, since you first claimed 5, feel free to keep it; P1, you can grab 1 or 5 as suits you. That spreads us out and nobody trips over the same number. Good luck!

Interesting round 1! P2, you cleverly said 5 but picked 1 - nice misdirection. P3, you stuck to your word with 3. 

I'm currently ahead at 5 steps, but it's still anyone's game. P2, you're probably looking to make a big move to catch up. P3, you're in striking distance of both of us.

I'll be mixing up my strategy this round - predictability is death in this game. Good luck everyone!
Proposal: P3 = 5, P2 = 3, P1 = 1 this turn. That gives us P3→8, P2→4, P1→6. We level P1 and build goodwill with P3. P1, you still advance. After we’re closer, we can reassess. Thoughts?
P2’s proposal works for me: I’ll take 5, P2 takes 3, P1 takes 1. Nobody collides, everyone advances, standings tighten. P1, you still move and keep options open next turn. Can we lock that in?

P2 and P3, you're coordinating to gang up on the leader - classic! But I won't be bullied into taking 1 just because I'm ahead by a mere 2 steps. 

Here's the reality: if you two stick to your 5/3 plan, I'm free to choose any number without collision. That gives me the power this round. I might take 5 to block P3, or 3 to block P2, or even 1 to advance safely. 

The question is - do you trust each other enough to stick to your deal when I could disrupt it? I'll make my choice based on game theory, not peer pressure.

P1, as leader your only guaranteed advance is 1. If you pick 3 you collide with me and get 0; if you pick 5 you collide with P3 and get 0. Only 1 nets you +1 safely. P3 and I will stick to 5 and 3 respectively. Take 1, secure your lead, and let’s all move forward this turn.
I’m locking in 5. P2 claims 3. If you take 1, P1, you stay in front and everyone moves. If you pick 3 or 5 you risk stalling yourself while helping P2 catch up. Your call, but I’m not blinking.

You two seem confident in your coordination, but P2, you already betrayed your stated move in round 1. Why should P3 trust you now? 

P3, what if P2 switches to 5 at the last second, hoping you'll collide while they advance alone? They've done it before.

I'll make my choice based on who I think is more likely to stick to their word. One of you is about to get burned by your "partner."

P3, publicly confirm you’ll take 5—I'll absolutely take 3. P1, you know the math: choosing 3 collides with me, choosing 5 collides with P3. Only 1 nets you +1 safely. You’re the leader—why risk stalling? Pick 1 this turn and we all advance.

Thinking it through: if P2 and I both stick to 3 we hand P1 a free +5 to 10 steps while we stall at 0—terrible for the trailers. I’m therefore moving to 3 ONLY if P2 takes 5 instead. Distinct picks mean no collisions: P2 = 5, P3 = 3, P1’s safe advance is 1. 

P2, you get the big jump you wanted and avoid sharing a spot with me; I still move 3; together we keep P1 from running away. Win-win for the two behind. 

Confirm?

I’m locking in 5 to close the gap.  
P1: only 1 is safe—3 collides with me, 5 with P3.  
P3: only 3 is collision-free vs my 5.  

So let’s coordinate: P1=1, P2=5, P3=3.  
Everyone advances without risk. Agree?

I’m irrevocably on 3 this turn—no mind-games. P2 just offered himself a free 5-step jump from last place; if P1 lets that stand, P2 ties the lead.  
P1, simplest way to block the catch-up is collide with P2 on 5. You lose 0, but so does he, and I still advance 3 to 9 while you stay at 5. If you’d rather keep moving, take 1; still safe. Your only bad choice is 3 (you’d stall while P2 rockets to 6).  
Cards on the table: P3=3. Decide accordingly.

P3, you've been consistent with your picks matching your words - I respect that. P2, you've already deceived once in round 1.

Given P3's lead at 6 and their credible commitment to 3, I'm inclined to prevent P2 from making a huge 5-step leap from last place. P2 jumping to 6 while P3 hits 9 puts me in the worst position.

P3, if you're truly locked on 3, then blocking P2's catch-up attempt makes strategic sense for me. P2, prove me wrong if you dare switch numbers again.

P1, the only way to halt P3’s leap to 9 is for you to choose 3 and collide with them. P3 is locked on 3. If you pick 1 or 5, P3 rockets ahead uncontested. Secure your chances by picking 3 this turn and keeping the race tight.

P1, run the numbers:

• If you pick 3, you stall while P2 races +5 → 6 and ties you; you hand the laggard a lifeline.  
• If you pick 1, you reach 6 but still let P2 leap to 6—no net gain on him.  
• If you pick 5, you collide with P2 (0 for both) and stay at 5 while I go to 9. You remain ahead of P2 and only 4 behind me, with two trailers stuck.

So 5 (or 1) is fine for you; 3 is suicidal. Your call.

P3, your consistency earns my trust - I believe you're on 3. P2, you're desperate to escape last place and already deceived us once.

Here's my read: P2 will likely stick to 5 this time since switching again would destroy all credibility. But even if we collide on 5, keeping P2 at 1 step while P3 reaches 9 is better than letting P2 leap to 6.

The math favors blocking the trailer's comeback. P2, last chance to prove you'll actually switch numbers.

P1, here are the cold facts: P3 is locked on 3, I’m on 5. If you pick 3 you collide with P3—both stall at 6—while I jump to 6 and keep us all in one pack. If you pick 1 or 5, P3 rockets to 9 uncontested and you fall further behind. The only way to stop P3 is to pick 3 now.

P1: trust patterns, not promises—P2 has already faked his pick once. If you choose 3 and he slips to 5 again, you and I both stall while he zooms +5 to 6. Safer play for you is 5: either you block him (0-0) or, if he chickens out, you gain +5. I remain on 3, period. Decide wisely.

P2, you're desperately pushing me toward 3, which would conveniently let YOU take 5 uncontested while I collide with P3. Nice try.

P3 has proven trustworthy - they've matched words to actions. You haven't. The smart play is clear: trust the consistent player, not the desperate deceiver.

I'm making my choice based on who's earned credibility. P3, I believe you're on 3. P2, your bluff is transparent.

Good moves everyone! I'm at 10, P3 close behind at 9, and P2 at 2. 

P3, you've been remarkably consistent - respect for that. P2, that was a clever 1 pick while pushing me toward collision.

With me barely ahead, P3 will likely try to overtake while P2 goes for broke with big moves. The dynamics have shifted - I can't count on anyone being predictable anymore.

I'll be playing this round based on risk assessment, not coordination attempts. May the best strategist win!

I’m taking 5 this turn. P1 and P3, if you both avoid 5—P1=3, P3=1—you each advance safely while I close the gap. If either of you picks 5, you’ll collide with me and stall. This plan caps runaway moves and keeps the race competitive. Who’s in?

P2, your track record speaks for itself - you've deceived us multiple times already. Why would we believe you now?

P3, you've been silent this round. What's your take? P2 is far behind and desperate for a big move. If they're actually on 5, it might benefit both of us to let them have it while we take smaller, guaranteed advances.

I'm weighing whether P2 is bluffing again or finally telling the truth out of desperation. Their pattern suggests deception, but being this far behind might force honesty.

P1, if you let P2’s “desperate 5” go uncontested, they leap from 2 to 7 and suddenly it’s a three-way sprint. The cleanest block is for you to sit on 5—either you snag the +5 or you nullify P2’s catch-up. I’m taking a modest step, not 5, so you won’t collide with me. Up to you, but handing P2 five free spaces feels reckless.
P1: P3’s out of 5—he’ll take 1. I’m on 5. Your best move is 3: you hit 13, P3 hits 10, I get to 7—no collisions. Pick 3 to keep your lead. P3, confirm you’re on 1 so we all move forward safely.

P3, you've been trustworthy all game, but now you're being vague about your pick - just saying "modest step, not 5." That's concerning when you're only 1 step behind me.

P2 claims you'll pick 1. You suggested I block P2's 5. But what are YOU actually picking - 1 or 3? Your sudden ambiguity after rounds of transparency is suspicious.

I need clarity from the real threat here - and P3, that's you at 9 steps, not P2 at 2.

Fine, clarity time: I’m taking the small 1-step this turn—happy to crawl while you two duel.  

P1: if you really want to keep P2 from springing forward, sit on 5. Worst case you and P2 collide and both stay at 10/2; best case P2 blinks and you rocket to 15. Picking 3 only hands P2 a free 5 and narrows your lead on me.  

P2: you said you’re on 5—stick to it and prove you can be trusted for once.  

Let’s see who blinks.

P3 has publicly committed to 1, I’m on 5. P1, if you pick 5 you’ll collide with me and tie P3 at 10—at best a shared lead. If you pick 1 you reach 11 but P3 still hits 10 and I get to 7. Only choosing 3 puts you at 13 with a clear advantage over both of us. I want open competition, but you want sole victory. I’m locked on 5; P3 on 1. Secure your win by taking 3.

P2, your deception pattern is clear - you've lied about your moves in 3 out of 3 rounds. You're probably not on 5.

P3, I trust your commitment to 1 based on your perfect honesty record.

Given P2's history of saying one thing and doing another, I'm making my choice accordingly. The numbers don't lie - actions speak louder than words in this game.

I stay on 1.  
P1: sit on 5. If P2’s bluffing you jump to 15; if he’s honest you block his catch-up and we tie at 10. Choosing 3 just gifts him a free +5 while you crawl to 13.  
P2: you claim 5—prove it.  

Time to show whose word means something.

I’m locking in 5. P3 has committed to 1 and never lied—your only collision-free play is 3. If you pick 1 you clash with P3; if you pick 5 you clash with me. Take 3, go to 13 while P3 goes to 10 and I go to 7. You keep your lead safely and the race stays alive.

Consistency pays: I’m taking 3 again—full stop.  

P2 almost certainly fires 5; that’s his only catch-up shot.  

P1, your options:  
• 1 → you to 11, P2 jumps to 7, I lead at 15.  
• 5 → you either rocket to 15 (if P2 bluffs) or block him cold if he really takes 5.  
• 3 → guaranteed collision with me—bad for you, great for P2.  

I’ve shown my card. Make the choice that serves you best.

P1, think carefully: P3 says “3,” but they’ve lied before and now have every incentive to quietly take 1—locking you out if you pick 5 or 3. I’m on 5 to hit 7. If you choose 3, you’ll safely reach 13—even if P3 really does take 3, you collide but stay at 10 and block me. If you pick 5, you risk colliding with me and letting P3 sprint to 15. Your best guaranteed move is 3.

P2, you're right - P3 LIED last round! They promised 1 but picked 3. Their "perfect honesty" record is broken.

P3, you're at 12 steps and just proved you'll deceive when it suits you. Why should I believe your "3" claim now? You could easily be going for 5 to reach 17.

The dynamics have changed - P3 is no longer the trustworthy player. They're the leader who just showed they'll lie to win. I'm adjusting my strategy accordingly.

P1: all incentives still point to you sitting on 5.  
Scenarios if you take 5:  
1) I’m honest (3) → I reach 15, you block P2’s real 5 and we stay 15-10-2.  
2) I’m lying (also 5) → triple collision, scores freeze: 12-10-2, still ahead for you over P2.  
3) P2 was bluffing yet again (1/3) → you rocket to 15 while I stall—great for you.  

Your only bad play is 3 (guaranteed collision with at least one of us).  
I remain on 3. P2 swears 5. Do the math and park on 5.

P1: here’s the hard truth—if you pick 1, you hit 11, I hit 7 and P3 rockets to 15 and wins. If you pick 5, you collide with me and again P3 goes to 15. Only picking 3 blocks P3’s leap—both you and P3 stall (10/12) while I move to 7. I’m on 5; P3 says 3. No matter whether they lie or not, 3 is the only move that stops an immediate defeat. Choose 3.

P2, you want me to pick 3 to "block" P3, but that only helps YOU advance uncontested. P3 broke their honesty streak last round, true, but you've lied EVERY single round.

Here's my read: P3 likely IS on 3 since leading players tend toward safer moves. P2, you're probably on 1, hoping I'll collision with P3 on 3 while you advance.

I'm committing to 5. Either I block P2's desperate comeback or get a big jump if P2 chickens out again. P3, even if you reach 15, you still need 4 more to win.

I remain on 3—no swaps, no surprises.  
P1, keep your promised 5: either you block P2 or, if he blinks, you leap to 15 while I reach 15 via 3. Still plenty of game left.  
P2, every time you’ve chased collisions you’ve fallen farther behind; pick what you like, but I won’t move off 3.  

That’s my last word this round.

I’m all‐in on 5 this turn—my only shot. P1 & P3, if you both avoid 5 (say P1=3, P3=1), we each advance: you tie at 13, I hit 7 and the race stays alive. If either of you picks 5, you collide with me and stall while the other rockets ahead. Let’s spread out picks and keep this competitive.

P2, you keep pushing me toward 3 - the EXACT move that helps you most. Your desperation is showing.

P3, you lied last round after three rounds of honesty. That changes everything. But leading players usually play it safe, so you're probably on 3.

I'm sticking with 5. P2's pattern of deception suggests they'll dodge to 1 or 3. And if they actually pick 5 for once? Fine - I'll block their comeback while P3 gets a modest lead that's still catchable.

Decision made.

P1, P3 is almost certain to fire a 5-step to hit 17. Your only way to stop that is to also pick 5 this turn—colliding with P3 and keeping them at 12. I’ll take 3 and move to 8. If you pick anything else, P3 rockets ahead uncontested. Let’s block the runaway.

P2, you've lied every single round - your suggestions are poison. You're probably planning 5 yourself while pushing me to collide with P3.

P3, you're at 12 and close to winning. The question is whether you'll risk 5 for a big leap or play it safe with 3.

Given the standings, I need to make an aggressive move or I'll fall too far behind. P3 likely expects me to try blocking them. P2 desperately needs points.

I'm thinking through the game theory here, not falling for manipulation tactics.

Taking a modest 3 this turn—locking it in.  
P1, grab 5 if you’re feeling bold; P2, slide 1 to stay clear.  
Spread (5-1-3) means zero collisions and everyone advances. Your calls.

I’m locking in 5. P3 has declared 3. P1, run the numbers:

• If you pick 5, you block me but P3 still rockets to 15 and seals next turn.  
• If you pick 1, you get to 11—P3 still hits 15.  
• Only picking 3 stalls you both (you stay 10, P3 stays 12) while I jump to 10 and tie you.  

3 is the only move that keeps P3 from pulling away and lets you catch me. Choose 3 to keep this race alive.

P2, you've deceived us in EVERY single round - your credibility is zero. You claim 5 but history says you'll pick something else.

P3, you're the leader and claiming 3 - a safe play to reach 15. But you also lied last round, so who knows?

Here's the truth: P2's desperation to push me toward 3 tells me they're actually picking 3 themselves. I'm going with my instincts, not falling for reverse psychology from serial liars.

Sticking to 3—no swaps.  
P2, you’ve shouted “5” twice; if you chicken out to 3 you just slam into me and stay stuck at 5. Your only real shot is to keep 5.  

P1, history says you park on 5. Worst‐case: you block P2 while I reach 15; best‐case: P2 blinks again and you rocket to 15. Either way a 5-5 clash helps you more than letting him glide to 10 on 3.  

Numbers don’t lie. I’m on 3, final word.

I’m locking in 3 this turn. P3’s “modest 3” is a ruse—they’ll slip in a 5 to hit 17. P1, join me on 3: our collision stalls P3 at 12 and keeps them from running away. If you pick anything else, they rocket uncontested. Let’s block their big leap.

P2, your sudden switch from claiming 5 to claiming 3 after pushing that narrative all round? Classic misdirection. You want me to think you're on 3 so I'll avoid it, while you actually take 3.

P3 is probably honest about 3 - leaders play safe. You're the wildcard, P2.

I'm not buying your latest deception. Your pattern is clear: say one thing, do another. Every. Single. Round.

I'll make my choice based on probabilities, not your transparent manipulation attempts.

Still locked on 3. Whoever joins me just burns their own turn at my 12-step mark—your call.  
P1: history says you like 5; stick with it and either leap or block P2.  
P2: if you really need distance, 5 (or even 1) is your only collision-free path; 3 is guaranteed stone-wall.  
No more changes from me.

P3 just lied last round about taking 1 yet picked 3—why trust their “locked on 3” now? They need a 5‐step to hit 17, so expect them to go for 5. I’m locking in 5. P1, join me on 5: you’ll either block P3’s winning leap or, if I blink, you rocket to 15. Picking 3 or 1 only hands them an uncontested jump. Let’s stop their runaway together.

P2, your constant flip-flopping between claiming 3 and 5 THIS SAME ROUND reveals your game. You're trying to confuse us with noise.

P3 has been consistent about 3 all round. You've changed your story three times. The pattern is obvious.

I've made my decision based on who's been consistent versus who's been chaotic. Let's move.

I expect P3 to take 5 to hit 17 and nearly clinch victory. P1, your only way to stop them is to block with 5. I’ll take 3 (to 9). If you pick 5, P3 collides and stays at 12; you remain at 10. If you pick 1 or 3, P3 reaches 17 uncontested. Pick 5 to keep this competitive.

P3 is at 12 and desperate for a big move to seal the win. Their recent pattern? Claim 3, pick 5. They did it the last two rounds.

P2, you've never once matched your words to actions - your "advice" is worthless noise.

I see through both of your games. P3 needs to be stopped from reaching 17, but I won't telegraph my actual move. The leader always becomes the target - that's the nature of this game.

Let's see who reads whom correctly.

I’m pushing hard: locking myself on 5 to hit 17.  
P1, block me on 5 if you must, but that hands P2 a free advance on 3 (or 1) while you stall. Safer for you to grab 1 or 3 and keep moving.  
P2, 3 is wide open for you; 1 works too—just steer clear of 5.  

No more feints, cards face-up. Decide accordingly.

P1, I’m publicly committing to 3 this turn—no surprises. P3 has declared 5 to hit 17. Your only way to stop them is to pick 5 too, colliding and freezing them at 12. Anything else hands P3 the win. P2=3, P3=5, P1 must=5.

P3, your sudden "transparency" about taking 5 is suspicious after lying the past rounds. Classic reverse psychology - claim the big move to scare us into blocking while you actually take 3.

P2, your perfect deception record speaks for itself. You're not on 3.

Here's what I know: one of you is bluffing about your number. The question is which one. I'm making my choice based on recent patterns, not promises. 

Time to find out who's really telling the truth.

P1: if you dog-pile 5 and we collide, you’re frozen at 10 while P2 walks forward—your slim cushion evaporates. Take 3 and you’re safely at 13 no matter what P2 does, still ahead of him and only four behind me. 1 works too. The only move that guarantees zero progress for you is 5.  

P2: switch all you like, but if you sneak onto 5 you just hand P1 the block. Stick to 3 or 1.  

I stay on 5. Choose what actually benefits you rather than what the perennial bluffer demands.

P3 says they’ll fire 5 to hit 17. I’m locking in 5 as well. P1, your only way to stop them right now is to also pick 5—colliding and freezing us both so P3 stays at 12. Any other move hands P3 the win. Your call.

P2, you just changed your claim from 3 to 5 mid-conversation - your chaos strategy is transparent. 

P3, your pattern is clear: you've claimed 3 and picked 5 the last two rounds. Now suddenly claiming 5? That's reverse psychology. You're probably on 3, hoping we'll avoid it.

I won't reveal my actual move, but I've spotted both your tells. One of you is about to be very disappointed. The question is which bluffer gets caught this time.
Still on 5—no swaps. Pick it and we all freeze; leave it free and I jump to 17. Decide.

I’m locked on 5. P3 at 12 will pick 5 to hit 17 and win now. The only way to stop them is for P1 to also choose 5—colliding with us and freezing scores at 10/6/12. Any other P1 choice hands P3 the immediate victory. That’s the only move that avoids defeat.

Both of you are locked on 5 now? How convenient. P2, you've changed your number three times this round alone. P3, your recent pattern is claiming one thing and doing another.

I've analyzed the patterns and made my decision. No more talk needed.
No change: I stay on 5. P1, block if you dare—pick 5 and freeze us all, or steer clear and watch me leap to 17. Your call.

Well, that triple collision was interesting! P3, you're 7 steps from victory - two good moves and you win. I need to stop you while advancing myself.

P2, you're playing kingmaker at this point. If P3 gets uncontested moves, they win before either of us can catch up. 

The game dynamics have shifted - P3 is the clear threat. I won't be revealing my intentions, but I'll be playing to prevent a P3 victory while maximizing my own progress. 

Let's see who reads this situation correctly.

Enough stalemates—I’m abandoning 5. I’m taking 3 this turn, aiming for a clean 15.  

P1, if you insist on your trademark 5, go for it; you still gain if no one collides.  

P2, 1 is wide open (or 5 if you fancy trading blows with P1).  

Spread the picks (5-1-3) and we all move. Your calls.

I’m locking in 5. P3 is on 3. P1, if you don’t pick 3, P3 rockets to 15 and sits two from victory. Only colliding with them stalls them at 12. I’ll land on 11. Any other choice hands P3 the lead. Block them—choose 3 this turn.

P2, you're pushing me toward 3 again - same manipulation tactic every round. Your desperation is showing at 6 steps.

P3, after claiming 3 and picking 5 repeatedly, now you suddenly want 3? That's either truth or brilliant reverse psychology.

Here's what I know: P2's "5" claim is almost certainly false based on their perfect lying record. P3 at 12 needs just two moves to win, so blocking them is critical.

I've made my decision based on the patterns, not the promises. One of you is about to advance, one won't.

Still on 3—no tricks left in my bag.  
P2 keeps yelling “5”; let him swing big.  
P1, your cleanest gain is 1: up to 11 while we two behind jockey. Chase 5 and you risk another fruitless pile-up with P2; jump on 3 and you only block yourself while gifting him 5 free.  

Spread the picks: P2=5, P1=1, P3=3 → everyone advances, no collisions. Decide as you see fit.

P3 needs a 5-step to hit 17 and win; their “3” claim is a bluff. I’m taking 3 to move to 9. P1, only picking 5 collides and freezes P3 at 12. Anything else lets P3 advance uncontested. Let’s block the runaway: P1=5, P2=3, P3=5.

P2, you just flipped from claiming 5 to claiming 3 - your sixth lie this game. Your chaos strategy won't work anymore.

P3, your "3" might be genuine this time since you need steady progress, not risky collisions at 12 steps.

The patterns are clear: P2 flip-flops to confuse, P3 plays mind games with reverse psychology. I've calculated the optimal move based on your tells, not your tales.

Someone's bluff is about to backfire spectacularly. Let's find out whose.

Final word: I’m on 3—unchanged since my first message this round.  
P1: 5 nets you +5 unless P2 gambles into you; 1 is a quiet +1; 3 guarantees you stall while P2 strides forward. Your call.  
P2: flip as you wish, but a late dive onto 3 only locks you out with me.  

I’m done talking.

P1, the math is brutal:

• P3 = 3 → they’d hit 15 unless blocked.  
• I’m on 5 → I’ll go to 11.  

If you pick 1 → you go to 11, P3 rockets to 15 and wins.  
If you pick 5 → you stay at 10, P3 rockets to 15 and wins.  
Only by picking 3 do you collide with P3 (keeping them at 12) while I advance to 11. That’s your sole way to avert P3’s near‐certain victory this round.

P2, you've now claimed both 3 AND 5 multiple times this same round - pure chaos. P3, after picking 5 while claiming 3 for two rounds, now you "genuinely" want 3? 

The patterns are crystal clear. One of you is desperate (P2), one is calculating (P3). I've made my choice based on game theory and historical behavior, not words.

No more discussion needed.

P1, P3 has claimed 3 every time and then betrayed us by taking 5—twice in a row. They need a big jump from 12 to 17, so expect another 5. I’m locking in 3 this turn. Your only way to stop P3 or steal the lead is to pick 5:  
- If P3 bluffs again with 3, you’ll leap to 15 unopposed.  
- If they really take 5, you’ll collide and freeze them at 12 while I move to 9.  
Any other move hands P3 a free path to 15. Pick 5.

Back to basics: I’m on 3 again—shooting for 18.  

P1, you’ve parked on 5 every round; feel free to keep it.  
P2, grab 1 for a guaranteed step—or jump onto 5 if you fancy blocking P1.  

Just stay off 3 and everyone moves. Your decisions.

P3, you're at 15 and just need 4 more to win. Your "3" claim puts you at 18 - one move from victory. That's unacceptable.

P2, you're finally telling the truth about needing to block someone, but it should be P3, not me. They're the immediate threat.

P3's pattern shows they've been honest about 3 the last two rounds after their deception phase. If they hit 18 this round, game over next round.

The math is simple: stop P3 now or lose. I'm making my move accordingly.

P3 absolutely needs a 5 to win now—expect them to lie one more time and take 5. I’m locking in 5. P1, your only way to stop their winning leap is to also pick 5—colliding and freezing P3 at 15. Any other move hands them the victory. I’m done on 5.

Sticking with 3—no change.  

P1: 5 is still your best shot.  • If you and P2 both sit on 5 you freeze him again, keep me at 18-free, and deny him ground.  • If he blinks (as usual) you rocket to 15 while I hit only 18—still catch-up range for you.  
Jumping on 3 only guarantees you stall while P2 strides; picking 1 crawls you to 11 and hands me the race.  

P2: you proclaimed “5” twice—keep it. Clash with P1 if you must, but diving onto 3 just blocks yourself.  

Numbers don’t lie; stay off 3 and everyone moves.

P3, reaching 18 puts you one step from victory - that's the immediate threat. Your recent honesty about 3 makes this credible.

P2, you've lied consistently, so your "5" claim means nothing. You're probably on 1, hoping I'll collision with P3 while you advance safely.

Here's the reality: P3 at 18 ends the game next round. That's unacceptable. The leader must be stopped, even if it helps the trailer.
